title: Transgender student who was kicked out of Baptist college moves back to Nashville, changes name
text:
CLOSE Yanna Awtrey is transgender and was kicked out of Welch College in Gallatin while recovering from "top surgery." Courtney Pedroza, Nashville Tennessean

NASHVILLE, Tenn. — It’s been two months since Yanna Awtrey was essentially kicked out of Welch College in Gallatin, Tennessee, after having breast reduction surgery, also known as “top surgery.” And while the transgender man has been transitioning physically, he’s also experienced an emotional journey that has led him back to the Nashville area despite how some community members have treated him.

Soon, he will also be legally changing his name.

Awtrey, whose parents are Free Will Baptist missionaries, spent most of his life with his family in Bulgaria, where they still live. Ever since he was 15, he knew his parents planned for him to attend Welch College in Gallatin — formerly Free Will Baptist Bible College.

But his decision to undergo the surgery in August led to him being outed to the college, and subsequently, a disciplinary committee suspended him for two years. If he wished to return, they said, he’d face another committee.

Alone in an unfamiliar country and town, Awtrey needed to find a place to live — and quickly.

He wound up in North Carolina at the home of his parents’ friends, who allowed him to stay long enough to recover physically from the surgery.

Previously reported: Transgender student kicked out of Baptist college after surgery

Last week, he returned to Nashville, to more family friends, despite everything that’s happened. Here’s why:

A separation

Growing up in Bulgaria, surrounded by conservative Christians, Awtrey said he didn’t meet an openly LGBT person until he was 18.

“I didn’t hear the word transgender until I was online at 16,” he said. “I met my first openly transgender person when I was 18. That was an exciting moment for me. It shows how very protected and secluded I was."

Awtrey continues to take hormones, and in a couple of weeks, he has a court hearing to legally change his name. That represents more to Awtrey than just a part of his physical transition.

“It’s a separation between my old life and my new life,” he said.

Who he is now has been a work in progress, Awtrey explained.

“I’ve kind of flip-flopped my mood,” he said, adding he was feeling depressed, especially in the first few weeks after everything happened with school.

“It was my general situation, where I suddenly didn’t have any home security or job security or life security – just the basic things people need and worry about,” he said.

But, Awtrey explained, he always prepared for this situation, and says he knew homelessness might be part of his journey.

“So whenever I get in that sort of mood, I understand it's just something that needs to pass over, that I need to work through and process. I know things, both good and bad, are temporary.”

LGBTQ: Homeless shelters could deny transgender people under proposed Trump administration rule

Yanna Awtrey poses for a photo at the home he is temporally staying in on Oct. 3 in Nashville, Tenn. (Photo: Courtney Pedroza / The Tennessean )

The effect on his faith

Awtrey said the experience with Welch College affected his faith — but in a positive way.

“I know there are people that call themselves Christians who wouldn’t behave the way these people did.

“Right now I think I’m in the best place I’ve been emotionally and spiritually because … growing up inside that community where I couldn't speak about what was on my mind and … what kinds of opinions I held without suspicions being cast on me, right now I’m separate from that, and so it’s now opening up a lot of new conversations … It’s made me dig deeper and I know myself more and I believe God more. And that relationship was a lot more fractured when I was closeted and living in Bulgaria."

While he still feels some anger, he said he doesn’t have a “personal anger toward Welch College.”

“I don’t feel like I need to spend time mulling over … every single aspect of what happened to me if it’s not going to make me a better person or make me choose different things in life.”

A look from the outside

Yanna Awtrey was kicked out of Welch College in Gallatin, Tenn., while recovering from surgery. (Photo: Courtney Pedroza / The Tennessean )

Since coming forward with his story, Awtrey said he’s heard from many people offering support and kindness. Some of them are former Welch students.

“Intuitively, I knew that these sorts of things happen all the time, but it’s another thing to read their stories in person and sort of connect to them,” he said. “I’m glad to make them feel seen and heard, even through my (story).”

One of the people who reached out was Nashville resident Kristine Kruczek Mains. One of Mains' children, 24-year-old Max, identifies as non-binary, and Mains said she strives to be an advocate. To her, that means actively seeking opportunities and relationships for people to be seen and heard, and participating in developing community awareness.

Mains said she wanted Awtrey to know he was not alone and that the person who is transitioning isn't really the one changing.

"They are who they have always been," she said. "We're the ones who have to transform our thinking about how we see people."

Mains reiterated that people shouldn't have to explain or justify who they are to anyone.

"You are loved and you are lovable in God's eyes, period," she said. "Anyone who sends you any message contrary to that is wrong."

Max Mains said if they could share anything with someone going through a similar experience, it would be that "it can feel really unfair. Like putting yourself out there in the world is essentially guaranteeing conflict."

"It's easy to really slide down into this dark place, questioning everything," they said.

But, Max Mains said, fight for yourself.

"You're responsible for the way you see your transitioning process, and you can see it as a really beautiful and complex act of self-protection and survival," they said. "The parts that often get pinched in the outside world are actually the parts of yourself worth creating space for the most."

'One step at a time'

Despite all the positive messages, Awtrey said his actions have been “minuscule.”

“I mean, I just tell my story, and that’s about it. It's just important to put a light on things that happen because otherwise nobody would talk about them … Instead of feeling more like I’m separate because my story has been told, it feels more and more like I’m interconnected to all these other … stories that have happened that haven’t been talked about.”

Awtrey said he realizes that he will meet people who disagree with his choices no matter where he goes.

“It’s the same people, just different faces and different names.”

Nashville actually feels like home, despite everything that's happened.

“Nashville is the most ... pro-LGBT place I’ve ever been," he said.

Awtrey said he’s planned for what has happened, and knows he’ll be OK.

“I just have faith in my own stubbornness, in my own ability to be a cockroach and survive. … It’s about what I imagined it would be and I mean, just one step at a time.”
